04.01.question: Use cases can vary from one organization to another in terms of the degree of formality employed.

04.02.question: It is common practice to create smaller, more focused use cases breaking the whole process down into parts.

04.03.question: Use cases will have inputs and outputs.

04.04.question: The actor in a use case is generally:

04.04.D.choice: An external user of the system

04.05.question: Use cases are especially valuable for business system applications and websites.

04.06.question: Which is probably NOT true about building use cases?

04.06.A.choice: External or internal triggers are analyzed

04.07.question: Use cases are especially valuable for batch processes, computationally intensive applications, and data warehousing.

04.08.question: Omar is an analyst building a use case. Which of the following project roles might be the most important in terms of getting information about building the use case?

04.09.question: Liang has identified the payroll authorization office as the actor in a use case. This would be incorrect as primary actors need to be singular like a customer or a patient or a student.

04.10.question: Role-playing the use case with actual users is a good way to do what?

04.10.C.choice: Identify the major steps within each use case

04.11.question: The most common ways to elicit information for use cases is with questionnaires of the affected users.

04.12.question: Use cases are a type of 'data-driven modeling'.

04.13.question: What is probably NOT a part of a use case?

04.14.question: A temporal trigger might be related to time, such as 30 days have passed and a late fee needs to be assessed.

04.15.question: Use cases give more detail about requirements.

04.16.question: Use cases sometimes are called 'business scenarios'.

04.17.question: Use cases normally contain ten to twelve major steps.

04.18.question: Ralph wants to illustrate how a system interacts with the environment. The best solution for him would be to use a what?

04.19.question: Use cases are always internal and rarely shared or discussed with business users.

04.20.question: Destination would be described on a use case in which of the following areas?

04.21.question: Dr. O'Brien's dental office calls a patient three days before an appointment. This could be an example of a temporal trigger.

04.22.question: Tina is a systems analyst and is describing how a system should react to an event. She is creating a use case.

04.23.question: Each use case has a name and a number.

04.24.question: Austin is a systems analyst. Which of the following people might be the most valuable to him in developing a use case for an accounts payable system upgrade?

04.24.A.choice: Beth, a software vendor for Peachtree Accounting Software

04.24.B.choice: Casey, a fellow analyst who is more experienced in making use cases

04.24.C.choice: Amy, a team manager in the accounts payable department

04.24.D.choice: Bill, a Java programmer in the applications development area.

04.24.E.choice: Lisa, the project manager for the project

04.25.question: Marta has asked the users of a system to picture themselves performing the processes and to write down those processes in a sequential order. She should get a good idea of what?

04.25.E.choice: The major steps for each use case

04.26.question: Use cases are diagrams with three components: selection, process, iteration.

04.27.question: A trigger is based on cost/benefit analysis, like an employee labor report, a sale of an item, or the purchase of new hardware.

04.28.question: The event that causes the use case to begin is referred to as the name.

04.29.question: The 'actor' is the external user that triggers the event to which the system responds.

04.30.question: Which of the following is probably NOT a step for writing a use case?

04.30.C.choice: Identify the major steps within each use case

04.31.question: External triggers might be something like a customer calling a doctor for an appointment or a student registering for a class.

04.32.question: Each use case contains a fairly complete description of all the activities that occur in response to a trigger event.

04.33.question: The actor of a use case refers to only a person that interacts with the system.

04.34.question: Barton is an analyst developing a use case. Which of the following will probably NOT be on his use case?

04.35.question: A 'temporal' trigger might be which of the following:

04.35.A.choice: The date changes to the first day of the month

04.35.B.choice: A new shipping of goods arrives and needs to be added to the inventory

04.35.C.choice: A patient calls to make an appointment with a doctor

04.35.D.choice: The accounting department needs information for a report

04.35.E.choice: The human resources department needs a tax withholding form to be filled out by a new employee

04.36.question: The final step in building use cases is to use a CASE analysis tool to verify that the inputs and outputs are discrete items triggered by external events.

04.37.question: Which of the following is probably NOT a part of most use cases?

04.38.question: Use cases generally have up to 20 major steps spelled out in great detail.

04.39.question: A use case is a formal way of representing how a business system interacts with its environment.

04.40.question: Project managers, business analysts and systems analysts create all use cases without user input.

04.41.question: Use cases can be identified by reviewing the functional requirements.

04.42.question: Use cases are a type of 'event-driven modeling'.

04.43.question: Each use case has a name, a number, importance level, brief description, primary actor, trigger, major inputs and outputs, and a list of major steps.

04.44.question: Which is NOT true of use cases?

04.44.A.choice: They illustrates the activities that are performed by the users of the system

04.44.B.choice: They illustrate what starts (or triggers) an event, all the people that are involved, and how the system provides value

04.44.C.choice: They sometimes are called 'business scenarios' (although 'use case' is generally preferred)

04.44.D.choice: They can be thought of as an external or functional view of a business process

04.44.E.choice: They are formal ways of representing how a business system interacts with its environment

04.45.question: When developing the major inputs and major outputs for a use case, the analyst and users should consider which of the following?

04.45.A.choice: What triggers these inputs and outputs

04.45.B.choice: Using activity elimination to see if these inputs and outputs are really needed

04.45.C.choice: Only the common inputs and outputs

04.45.D.choice: All possible inputs and outputs (even with rare occurrences)

04.45.E.choice: Developing separate use cases for every possible input and every possible output

04.46.question: Use cases are used to more fully delineate what?

04.47.question: Use cases are always numbered sequentially from start to finish.

04.48.question: Special cases (like customer cancels an appointment or returns an item) are what?

04.48.A.choice: Not of importance at this stage

04.48.C.choice: Given use case ID's of "SC" (for special case) and a number

04.48.E.choice: Written as exceptions at the bottom of the relevant use case

04.49.question: Use cases can vary from one organization to another in terms of the content included.

04.50.question: Each use case has the same name (like "Customer Relationship Management System") followed by an identifying letter ("A", "B", etc.).

04.51.question: The 'actor' is the internal action that occurs based on a SQL query (like: sort, select).

04.52.question: Barb is an analyst developing a use case. Which of the following will probably NOT be on her use case?

04.53.question: A use case depicts a set of activities performed to produce some output result.

04.54.question: Triggers are referred to as external or internal.

04.55.question: After working with Chris (who is a staff member in the registrar's office) on major steps in the registration process, Maureen (a systems analyst) will next do what?

04.55.E.choice: Discuss these steps with Thomas, the project manager

04.56.question: Use cases illustrate the activities that are performed by the users of the system.

04.57.question: As a last step in building a use case for the study-abroad registration system, Brianna will do what?

04.57.A.choice: Ask Drew in the students affairs office to confirm the use case

04.57.B.choice: Ask Patrick in the study abroad office to confirm the use case

04.57.C.choice: Ask Wendy in the registrar's office to confirm the use case

04.57.D.choice: Ask Jonathan, a student who just completed a study-abroad experience, to confirm the use case

04.57.E.choice: Ask Taylor, another systems analyst to confirm the use case

04.58.question: You might have to go back and adjust the steps in a use case, if what happens?

04.58.A.choice: There are more than three major inputs to a step

04.58.C.choice: The primary actor is an external customer

04.58.D.choice: The trigger is an external one

04.58.E.choice: The steps are of varying size

04.59.question: A use case helps do which of the following?

04.59.B.choice: Clarify ongoing costs for a system

04.60.question: Some organizations may choose to include additional sections on their use case forms, these may include which of the following?
